title: 110_hr3513
content: The "Copper Salmon Wilderness Act of 2008" designates the Copper Salmon Wilderness. The Oregon Wilderness Act of 1984 is amended to designate approximately 11,922 acres of land in the Siskiyou National Forest as the Copper Salmon Wilderness. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to file a map and legal description of the wilderness with the Senate and House Committees on Energy and Natural Resources. The Copper Salmon Wilderness designation under the Oregon Wilderness Act of 1984 includes filing a map and legal description with the Senate and House Committees on Energy and Natural Resources. The filed documents have the same legal force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct typographical errors. The boundary of the wilderness near a road can have an offset of up to 150 feet, and the maps are available for public inspection at Forest Service offices. SEC. 3. WILD AND SCENIC RIVER DESIGNATIONS, ELK RIVER, OREGON. Section 3(a)(76) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to designate specific segments of the North Fork Elk and South Fork Elk rivers in Oregon as scenic or wild rivers. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act designates specific segments of the South Fork Elk river in Oregon as scenic or wild rivers, including a 0.9-mile segment from its source downstream to Forest Service Road 3353, and a 4.2-mile segment from the road to its confluence with the North Fork Elk. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF TRIBAL RIGHTS. This Act does not diminish any rights of Indian tribes. The Secretary aims to make an agreement with the Coquille Indian Tribe for access to the Copper Salmon Wilderness for historical and cultural activities. SEC. 5. DESIGNATION OF POTENTIAL WILDERNESS AREA, SISKIYOU NATIONAL FOREST, OREGON. Designation of certain National Forest System land in Oregon as a potential wilderness area for inclusion in the Copper Salmon Wilderness. The Secretary will provide a map and legal description to relevant committees. The Secretary will manage the potential wilderness area designated as wilderness until its official designation. Ecological restoration may involve the use of motorized equipment and mechanized transport until completion. The Secretary may use motorized equipment and mechanized transport in the potential wilderness area until its official wilderness designation, with the goal of minimizing adverse impacts on wilderness character and resources. The potential wilderness area will be designated as wilderness either when conditions incompatible with the Wilderness Act are removed or 10 years after the enactment of the Act. The potential wilderness area designated by the Act will be incorporated into the Copper Salmon Wilderness and administered according to the Wilderness Act and other relevant laws. Any reference in the Wilderness Act to its effective date will apply to the date of designation as wilderness under the Act. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 22, 2008.
